article_title: From Sea To Shining Sea: French And US Sunshine Laws
article_text:
From Sea To Shining Sea: French And US Sunshine Laws

Law360, New York (May 22, 2014, 5:09 PM ET) -- In the words of the former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis, sunshine may well be the best disinfectant, but different countries have very different ideas on where health care industry transparency is needed.



In the U.S., intense scrutiny in recent years has focused on relationships between drug and medical device manufacturers on one hand and physicians and teaching hospitals on the other. New requirements by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, effective this year, will require public disclosure of these relationships.

article_metadata.description: While sunshine may be the best disinfectant, different countries have very different ideas on where health care transparency is most needed. The passage of sunshine regulations governing the relationships between drug companies and health care providers — and the differences between those rules in the U.S. and France — are sure to impact aggregate spending, litigation risks and compliance efforts in both countries, say Elizabeth Carder-Thompson and Daniel Kadar of Reed Smith LLP.
